Title.evidence: This randomized clinical trial used a stepped-wedge design

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomized clinical trial used a stepped-wedge design to randomly assign patients to a QPL intervention (n = 223) or usual care (n = 223)

Participants.evidence: Patients were 60 years or older with at least 1 comorbidity and an oncologic or vascular (cardiac, neurosurgical, or peripheral vascular) problem that could be treated with major surgery.

Intervention.evidence: A brochure of 11 questions to ask a surgeon developed by patient and family stakeholders plus an endorsement letter from the surgeon were sent to patients before their outpatient visit.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To compare the effectiveness of a question prompt list (QPL) intervention vs usual care on patient engagement and well-being among older patients considering major surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary well-being outcomes included (1) the difference between patient’s Measure Yourself Concerns and Well-being (MYCaW) scores reported after surgery and scores reported after the surgical visit and (2) treatment-associated regret at 6 to 8 weeks after surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: This randomized clinical trial used a stepped-wedge design to randomly assign patients

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 1319 patients eligible for participation, 223 were randomized to the QPL intervention and 223 to usual care.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The difference in MYCaW scores for family members was greater in usual care (effect estimate, 1.51; 95% CI, 0.28-2.74; P = .008).
